Unless you're a die-hard fan, you won't recognize these characters, but what you will recognize is people dealing with trauma. I deeply enjoyed this film as a long-time Marvel fan along with my wife (who has zero knowledge of this stuff) because the themes are relatable. Each character deals with grief, irrelevance, regret, disappointment, and loss in a way that resonates with the audience. I read some really harsh reviews, but I actually enjoyed the film a lot more than I thought I would. It's not a perfect film, by any means. However, it does keep a really tight grip on the plot and doesn't muddy the waters too much with the ensemble cast, instead (wisely) choosing to focus on the three main leads. Their arcs are compelling, emotional, and real. I do wish that some of the characters had more time to bond and that some of the plot devices weren't so obvious (such as visible countdown timers for traps and easily located bomb power supplies), but they don't detract from the emotional beats. I liked that they take their name from Yelena's childhood team, the "Thunderbolts," a soccer team that "never won a game." Phrasing is important -- it's not that they're losers, it's just that they've never won. To date, each character is dealing with 'victories' that are either morally gray or pyrrhic, so they all feel like underachievers. As underdogs, it's hard not to root for them.

I'm often a super hero movie skeptic. The worst super hero movies wind up being the all powerful hero versus the indestructible villain gallavanting through a city causing massive destruction amounting to nothing. Thunderbolts* felt like the antithesis of this. Every one of the characters was very human and very flawed. None -- even the powerful villain, was indestructible. And much of the movie actually focused on the very real issue of mental health. Multiple of the characters were grappling with mental health making them feel all that more real and human. On top of this, the writing was pretty humorous. Florence Pugh and David Harbour had the best characters, constantly throwing out witty one liners. And Julia Louis-Dreyfus was surprisingly good as Tulsi Gabbard -- I mean the evil CIA director. I never remember any of the broader plot lines from the Marvel universe and there were definitely a lot of references back to things that happened that I no longer remember from past movies. But it never felt like it mattered that I didn't remember. Overall it was a well put together, humorous movie that seemed to have a much more meaningful point than many vacuous superhero movies.

Thunderbolts is a strong, surprisingly grounded entry in the MCU that reminds us just how good Marvel can be when it actually leans into character, humor, and tight storytelling. With a cast of familiar faces and morally gray heroes, the film strikes a great balance between gritty action and sharp wit. The acting is consistently solid across the board, with returning characters like Yelena Belova and Bucky Barnes stealing scenes with both emotional depth and comedic timing. The chemistry between the team is believable, messy, and entertaining‚Äîjust what you‚Äôd want from a group of reluctant allies. The writing is smart and refreshingly character-driven, with enough humor to keep things light without undercutting the stakes. Action sequences are punchy, well-choreographed, and serve the story rather than overwhelm it. Thunderbolts may not reinvent the genre, but it doesn't need to. It's a reminder that Marvel still knows how to deliver a fun, engaging, and well-made superhero movie when it stays focused. A solid win that earns its place in the lineup.

What scared me about Thunderbolts is that, it felt like I was watching myself, specially from 2021/22. Those were my darkest days, the most I‚Äôve ever felt alone in my life up till now. It doesn‚Äôt help that I‚Äôm also the youngest of a sister duo. Lol. I felt numb. Cold. .. helpless. Stayed in my room. Threw myself in my art & writing. I had no friends to talk too truly about how I felt in my head or thoughts of .. ending it. It wasn't a coincidence that the film was also released during mental awareness month or that each character has had their fair share of pain and trauma. from the writing to acting, I wanted more. I crave more from the dynamic. This type of misfit team up, reminiscent of the Avengers 2012 film, is exactly what's been missing especially since guardians are no more. My only issues was, I wanted more Bucky, I wanted to see more of his life, home, job. Bucky is constantly getting the short end of the stick. (Just to clarify my sis is still alive, lmao)

When the rest of the team enters the Void, it doesn‚Äôt show any scene development, rather than suddenly appearing while Yelena and Bob were in the attic. You could add how they got into the Void, face their fears, so that the plot thickens. 2.Taskmaster was killed off too fast, we haven‚Äôt gotten to known her entire story, if she had survived, we would have gotten to explore the character‚Äôs personality and embrace her into the MCU. 3. The actors did a solid job with what they were given but honestly the material just didn‚Äôt hold up. The last 20 minutes were the only part that actually felt interesting. There was something deeper there, some Carl Jung style exploration of the shadow self. But it came way too late. The rest of the movie, like a full hour and 45 minutes, was just nonstop banter and silliness. No one was playing the real stakes of any situation. It‚Äôs like every Marvel character now has to sound like they‚Äôre in a Deadpool movie or some Thor Love and Thunder spinoff. Who at Marvel decided that‚Äôs the only way these movies can work? It‚Äôs exhausting. The thing is, humor can work really well in these films but only when it comes from character and from real emotion. Like with Robert Downey Jr.‚Äôs Iron Man. When he made a joke it felt earned. It came from pain or stress or just trying to stay sane in the middle of chaos. But now it‚Äôs just quip after quip for no reason and it kills any tension or emotional weight. Bottom line, I left the theater more annoyed than anything. There was potential but most of it was buried under cheap jokes and lazy writing.

Thunderbolts is an impressive film with a standout cast, especially Florence Pugh, who delivers a deeply emotional performance. The tone of the movie is notably darker compared to other Marvel films, giving it a unique and gritty atmosphere. The story skillfully builds sympathy for these former villains, making the audience truly connect with their journey by the film‚Äôs end. Overall, Thunderbolts offers a fresh, compelling take on the superhero genre that resonates on both an emotional and narrative level.

For longtime Marvel fans and newcomers alike, Thunderbolts offers a refreshing take on the superhero genre. The film stands out with its strong character dynamics and an impressive ability to balance heartfelt sincerity with sharp, well-timed humor. Rather than leaning too heavily in either direction, it allows its characters to shine through genuine emotional moments and light, engaging dialogue. Many reviewers agree that Thunderbolts brings a renewed sense of fun and energy to the Marvel lineup, offering a more enjoyable and memorable experience than some of its recent predecessors. In short, it‚Äôs a reminder of what makes Marvel stories resonate‚Äîdon‚Äôt miss it.

A significant shift in tone and quality from many ill-received installments that plagued MCU long after Endgame, Thunderbolts* may still pale compared to pre-Infinity Saga installments but it still serves as a refreshing reversal to quality Marvel flicks.

Thunderbolts* is the movie that not only gives you great action sequences and funny moments, it goes for your heart. These characters are broken, but they all find each other and like some weird superhero support group, manage to do the one thing that superheroes stopped doing in these films... they save the people. They're not looking to stop some cataclysmic, world ending event or cut the head off of a maniacal villain. Meanwhile dealing with real issues that haven't been touched upon very much (if at all) in these type of films. Trauma, self-harm, abuse, etc. Honestly, I haven't teared up in front of a superhero film since Black Panther. Lewis Pullman steals the show and his chemistry with Florence Pugh is a cinematic chef's kiss. There's laughs where they belong as well, with David Harbour nailing ever bit he was given. There are some things that could've been left out and naturally some things that needed further exploration. Like Julia Louis-Dreyfus who should've played a straight-laced hard case instead of Selina Meyer 2.0 Maybe there's an extended cut that delves more into the experiences of Ghost and Red Guardian, we don't get enough of their backstory. This is due to the fact that you're expected to know already. For the record, I don't care for the connected universe trope. Especially when we have to do our homework to know what's going on. That being said, I've been riding with Marvel from year one, so I know what's going on. Thunderbolts* falls short on a few things but it hits everywhere that truly matters and that's enough for me.

This movie exceeded my expectations! I was pleasantly surprised at how well this movie was directed based on its story, message, characters, and their development. I will not spoil anything, but I will say that after quite a few disappointing Marvel movies and series (with a few exceptions), Thunderbolts*, in my book, should be considered as one of the best Marvel movies of all time! This film has brought the MCU back to life. Can‚Äôt wait to see future Marvel films with the thunderbolt cast.

Cons: I'd say there was a bit too much forced humor which took away from scenes that were supposed to be intense. Also, I would have liked to see more from Bucky in this movie, and while Yelena is great, Marvel needs to be more careful about which characters they give the most lime-light to. Just because a big name actor plays a character (Florence Pugh), doesn't mean that character has to be the lead (another great example of this was Emilia Clark's G'iah). It hurts to think about how this movie deprived fans of a Bucky-lead film which is what I think everyone was hoping for to an extent. Unfortunately, I don't think Bucky is going to last much longer in the MCU, and I hardly doubt he'll be in another movie that would give him the chance to play that titular character. Again, while Florence Pugh's Yelena was great, that doesn't mean she has to lead a film in which there is another clear character (Bucky) who should have been the lead and deserved to be at this point. Pros: This is definitely one of the best Marvel movies I have seen in a while. It was heartfelt, emotional, and fun. I even found myself crying at one point which has only every happened to me 3 times before while watching a Marvel movie (Avengers: Endgame, Guardians of the Galaxy Volume 3, and Spider-Man: No Way Home). The action was on point, especially towards the third act. Also, the soundtrack was great.

The MCU is back! Thunderbolts* was just the jolt the MCU needed to give its narrative a heartbeat again. I always enjoy the MCU, and while not all entries can be the best one yet this one leads it all in the right direction. I thoroughly enjoyed almost every moment of this movie. Which is way more then I can say about the previous entry (Brave New World). Nothing here seemed repetitive in story telling and recycled without acknowledgement. Florence Pugh does a fantastic job bringing character and warmth to the what could be cookie cutter material. She digs in without over doing it and delivers her dialogue with great nuance. The rest of the cast is fleshed out beautifully. I was excited to see Wyatt Russell back in the MCU as well as Hannah John-Kamen (Ghost). This unique lineup that was not forced played out beautifully. Some cheeky cliche moments occurred, but you have to sometimes accept that. They weren't bad moments and give you hope for more moments to come. Plus some great nods to previous MCU moments. I appreciated the setting of this back in New York and at the Avengers/Stark/Watchtower. They are leaning into building a history for this site very well! Lewis Pullman has become a new favorite actor of mine and seeing him come into the MCU as the Entry/Void was perfect. The overused trope of Villain within the walls of the story was getting frustrating, but the Sentry story I became very open to. Lewis Pullman may have had a lot to do with that. Not having a formal villain to rid the earth of can often lead to an unsatisfying result (Brave New World) and is best works for Marvel TV shows, not the movies. This time was perfect. It might have been the build up for the future of the MCU and Avengers movies that helped also move this along or inspire greatness, but Ill take it and look very much to seeing this team again. The downfall if you really look at is this is its a repeat of Avengers: Age of Ultron. Just different characters and an updated story. We have our Ultron/Vision arc much repeated here but motives and reasons why things were happening is where things differ. I don't mind this, you don't really notice it unless your like me and really dig into the story. There is only so many reasons for scenarios to exist, its recreating them that becomes the interesting part and Thunderbolts* did so very well. Lastly....ill never get sick of seeing Bucky in the MCU. Sebastian Stan is wonderful and they continue to write him in in such subtly appropriate ways to not exploit his character and for that Im appreciative. Any scenes with Bucky certainly stood out bridging the old and new that creates distinct moments for this long time character of the MCU!

Thunderbolts* ‚Äì A Surprisingly Sharp, Gritty, and Grounded Marvel Entry Thunderbolts* might just be the shot of adrenaline the MCU needed. It trades in the world-ending sky beams and multiverse chaos for something grittier, more personal, and refreshingly human. What I loved most is how the film manages to feel *grounded*‚Äîwhile still delivering the action and spectacle you‚Äôd expect from a Marvel production. The cast absolutely clicks. The chemistry between these morally grey, damaged characters is electric, and it‚Äôs fascinating to watch a team of antiheroes try (and often fail) to work together. It‚Äôs not about perfect heroes saving the day‚Äîit‚Äôs about broken people trying to find redemption in a world that‚Äôs already written them off. Every character is given space to shine‚Äîno one fades into the background. Whether it's Yelena's sharp wit and emotional complexity, Bucky's inner conflict, or Red Guardian's layered mix of humor and regret, the film nails the ensemble dynamic without ever feeling overcrowded. The tone is darker, yes, but never dull. There‚Äôs weight to the decisions, actual consequences to the action, and the tension doesn‚Äôt come from magical MacGuffins‚Äîbut from the characters themselves, their pasts, and their uneasy alliances. It feels like a Marvel movie for grown-ups‚Äîwithout being grim for the sake of it. The action is tight, brutal, and real. There‚Äôs a physicality to it that makes it hit harder than most recent MCU entries. It‚Äôs not just noise‚Äîit‚Äôs storytelling through combat, and it works. In short, Thunderbolts* is bold without being loud, emotionally resonant without being melodramatic, and action-packed without losing sight of its characters. It might not be the flashiest Marvel film, but it‚Äôs one of the most mature, well-balanced, and compelling ones in recent years. Highly recommended‚Äîespecially if you‚Äôve been waiting for Marvel to take a risk that *pays off*
